title: Tremandraceae
text:
Tremandraceae <a href="Robert%20Brown%20%28botanist%2C%20born%201773%29">R.Br.</a> ex <a href="A.%20P.%20de%20Candolle">DC.</a> is the <a href="Botanical%20name">name</a> of a defunct <a href="Family%20%28biology%29">family</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s. It contained three <a href="genera">genera</a>: "<a href="Platytheca">Platytheca</a>", "<a href="Tetratheca">Tetratheca</a>", and "<a href="Tremandra">Tremandra</a>". In 2006, a <a href="molecular%20phylogenetic">molecular phylogenetic</a> study showed that Tremandraceae is embedded in <a href="Elaeocarpaceae">Elaeocarpaceae</a>. Recognizing Tremandraceae as a separate family would make Elaeocarpaceae <a href="paraphyletic">paraphyletic</a>. 
Tremandraceae was first recognized by <a href="Robert%20Brown%20%28botanist%2C%20born%201773%29">Robert Brown</a> in 1814, as Tremandreae, before the suffix - aceae was used to denote plant families. Brown's name was not validly published, but the name was <a href="Valid%20name%20%28botany%29">validated</a> by <a href="Augustin%20Pyramus%20de%20Candolle">Augustin Pyramus de Candolle</a> in 1824. The name Tremandreae is still sometimes used for this group, but at the <a href="taxonomic%20rank">taxonomic rank</a> of <a href="Tribe%20%28biology%29">tribe</a>.
